dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.ImageView
dynGuiComponents.contentDescription: Android System notification: USB debugging connected

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text:
Welcome to andOTP, this wizard will guide you through the initial setup. Please pay attention and read carefully otherwise you could lose data! 

Don't worry, you can still change any of the options later in the Settings.

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.ImageView
dynGuiComponents.contentDescription: Android System notification: Virtual SD card

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.ImageView
dynGuiComponents.contentDescription: Android System notification: USB debugging connected

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text: To ensure the security of your accounts andOTP only stores them in encrypted data files. Here you can choose which method of encryption will be used.

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text: This method will encrypt your data with a key generated from a password or PIN. The main advantage here is that this will work with external backup solutions (like Titanium) and is much less failure-prone than the KeyStore. However, you will have to enter your credentials every time you start andOTP.

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.ImageView
dynGuiComponents.contentDescription: Android System notification: Virtual SD card

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.ImageView
dynGuiComponents.contentDescription: Android System notification: USB debugging connected

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text: Here you can setup an authentication to lock andOTP. Since you have chosen Android KeyStore as encryption method this is optional.

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text: Please set a password to continue!

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text: To ensure the security of your accounts andOTP only stores them in encrypted data files. Here you can choose which method of encryption will be used.

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text: This method will encrypt your data with a key generated from a password or PIN. The main advantage here is that this will work with external backup solutions (like Titanium) and is much less failure-prone than the KeyStore. However, you will have to enter your credentials every time you start andOTP.

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.ImageView
dynGuiComponents.contentDescription: Android System notification: Virtual SD card

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.ImageView
dynGuiComponents.contentDescription: Android System notification: USB debugging connected

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text: To ensure the security of your accounts andOTP only stores them in encrypted data files. Here you can choose which method of encryption will be used.

dynGuiComponents.name: android.widget.TextView
dynGuiComponents.text:
The KeyStore is a system component of Android for securely storing cryptographic keys. The advantage of this method is that the keys are stored separated from the data files and can be backed by hardware cryptography (if your device supports it). However, as the keys are not stored with the apps data, this method prevents external backup solutions (like Titanium) from working. If you choose this method you will have to rely on the internal backup functions provided by andOTP. 

Warning: The KeyStore is known to cause a lot of problems, please only use it if you absolutely have to. If you don't mind entering a password / PIN every time you start andOTP it is highly recommended to use the password-based encryption instead.
